paragraphs.text:
%angular

What does this demo showcase?

The New York City Taxi & Limousine Commission has released the detailed historical dataset covering over 1.1 billion individual taxi trips in the city from January 2009 through June 2015. In this Analytics demo we only use data for Year 2013. We manage the trip and fare data in two tables (NYC_TAXI_TRIP, TAXI_TRIP_FARE). Each trip contains information like the driver's license info, the pickup and dropoff times and their precise locations, etc. The fare table contains the total charge along with tip amounts for each trip. The schema for the table is below. Each table is over a 150 million records and instead of managing all the data in memory we simply create two stratified samples. This requires only a fraction of the memory that would otherwise be required. In this demo, we showcase the following:

  1. Execute the query on the exact data noting the time it takes to parse parquet data and execute the query using Spark parallel processing (LEFT PARAGRAPHS)
  2. Execute the same query using Approximate Query Processing (AQP) engine noting both the accuracy and response time of the answer. (RIGHT PARAGRAPHS)
  3. We illustrate various features: constraining the error in query responses, Automatically swapping the approximate visualized plot with an exact response, projecting error rates as part of the query response and automatic query re-routing to underlying data source when error constraints cannot be satisfied.
NOTE: The data set used here is relatively small (few GB of Parquet formatted data). The interesting thing about using stratified sampling is that the error rate drops exponentially with the size of the sample. The exponential error drop off implies with larger data sets, the sampling fraction can also keep getting smaller. e.g. you may need a 2 million sample for a data set with 200 million records, but, may only need a 3 million sample for a data set with a billion records to achieve the same level of accuracy. Hence, the performance delta with sampling will be proportional to the data set size.
Anonymous user needs to clone this notebook to execute the paragraphs. Clone option available in the pane next to name of the notebook at the top of the page.

msg.data:
What does this demo showcase?

The New York City Taxi & Limousine Commission has released the detailed historical dataset covering over 1.1 billion individual taxi trips in the city from January 2009 through June 2015. In this Analytics demo we only use data for Year 2013. We manage the trip and fare data in two tables (NYC_TAXI_TRIP, TAXI_TRIP_FARE). Each trip contains information like the driver's license info, the pickup and dropoff times and their precise locations, etc. The fare table contains the total charge along with tip amounts for each trip. The schema for the table is below. Each table is over a 150 million records and instead of managing all the data in memory we simply create two stratified samples. This requires only a fraction of the memory that would otherwise be required. In this demo, we showcase the following:

  1. Execute the query on the exact data noting the time it takes to parse parquet data and execute the query using Spark parallel processing (LEFT PARAGRAPHS)
  2. Execute the same query using Approximate Query Processing (AQP) engine noting both the accuracy and response time of the answer. (RIGHT PARAGRAPHS)
  3. We illustrate various features: constraining the error in query responses, Automatically swapping the approximate visualized plot with an exact response, projecting error rates as part of the query response and automatic query re-routing to underlying data source when error constraints cannot be satisfied.
NOTE: The data set used here is relatively small (few GB of Parquet formatted data). The interesting thing about using stratified sampling is that the error rate drops exponentially with the size of the sample. The exponential error drop off implies with larger data sets, the sampling fraction can also keep getting smaller. e.g. you may need a 2 million sample for a data set with 200 million records, but, may only need a 3 million sample for a data set with a billion records to achieve the same level of accuracy. Hence, the performance delta with sampling will be proportional to the data set size.

paragraphs.text:
%spark z.put("aws_id",z.textbox("AWS Access ID")) z.put("aws_secret",z.textbox("AWS Secret Key")) println(s"""%angular
  • Access Credentials
    • Please refer to security credentials guidelines here.
    • The Zeppelin notebooks store state to disk. Using credentials via notebooks will result in them being written to disk. More about Zeppelin storage options is available here
    • If user still chooses to use notebooks as the mode of setting credentials, then user may clone this notebook and delete it immediately after completing use.
    """) z.run("20191206-005155_296046020")

paragraphs.title: [Auto run]
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
exec scala
org.apache.hadoop.fs.FileSystem.closeAll()
sc.hadoopConfiguration.set("fs.s3a.access.key", "{aws_id}")
sc.hadoopConfiguration.set("fs.s3a.secret.key", "{aws_secret}")

paragraphs.title: Schema for the table NYC_TAXI_TRIP
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
exec scala
snappy.table("nyc_taxi_trip").printSchema

paragraphs.title: Comparing the number of records in base table and Sample table
paragraphs.text: %md

paragraphs.title: How many rows in the Trip table?

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: How many rows using AQP? Actual count in sample?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
-- Fetch count. count(*) is the estimate. 'sample_count' is built-in alias to showing the actual number of records
-- in the selected sample 'with error 0.1' - allow a maximum of 10% error in the answer. 

select count(*) count, count(*) sample_count from nyc_taxi_trip with error 0.1 ;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Comparing the ride per week

paragraphs.title: Number of Rides per week
Number of Rides per week  (Use AQP)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql 

-- 'With error 0.1' - allow 10% error and if cannot be met run against full table
select count(*) numOfRides, weekofyear(pickup_datetime) from nyc_taxi_trip 
group by weekofyear(pickup_datetime) with error 0.1;
%md

paragraphs.title: What are the worst times of day to take a cab from midtown to JFK airport?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

-- A more selective query: filtered on two locations in manhattan

select avg(trip_time_in_secs/60) tripTime, hour(pickup_datetime) hr, count(*) howManyTrips from nyc_taxi_trip where 
round(pickup_latitude,2) >= round(40.754931,2) and 
 round(pickup_longitude,2) <= round(-73.974019,2) and 
round(pickup_latitude,2) <= round(40.757321,2) and  
round(pickup_longitude,2) >= round(-73.995194,2) and 
round(dropoff_latitude,2) >= round(40.632471,2) and 
round(dropoff_longitude,2) <= round(-73.765469,2) and 
round(dropoff_latitude,2) <= round(40.660735,2) and 
 round(dropoff_longitude,2) >= round(-73.799458,2) 
group by  hour(pickup_datetime) order by hr;

paragraphs.title: What are the worst times of day to take a cab from midtown to JFK airport?   (Use AQP)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
-- Note the directive 'with error' so we get and approximate answer

select avg(trip_time_in_secs/60) tripTime, hour(pickup_datetime) hr, count(*) howManyTrips from nyc_taxi_trip where 
round(pickup_latitude,2) >= round(40.754931,2) and 
round(pickup_longitude,2) <= round(-73.974019,2) and 
round(pickup_latitude,2) <= round(40.757321,2) and  
round(pickup_longitude,2) >= round(-73.995194,2) and 
round(dropoff_latitude,2) >= round(40.632471,2) and 
round(dropoff_longitude,2) <= round(-73.765469,2) and 
round(dropoff_latitude,2) <= round(40.660735,2) and 
 round(dropoff_longitude,2) >= round(-73.799458,2) 
group by  hour(pickup_datetime) order by hr with error;
%md

paragraphs.title: How does ridership change over months?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
-- Query will take more than 20 seconds. And, this is just one year's data.

select count(*) numOfRides,CASE 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 1 THEN 'Jan' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 2 THEN 'Feb' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 3 THEN 'Mar' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 4 THEN 'Apr' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 5 THEN 'May' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 6 THEN 'Jun'
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 7 THEN 'Jul' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 8 THEN 'Aug' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 9 THEN 'Sep' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 10 THEN 'Oct' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 11 THEN 'Nov' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 12 THEN 'Dec'
END AS mnt from nyc_taxi_trip group by month(pickup_datetime) 
order by month(pickup_datetime);

paragraphs.title: How does ridership change over months? (Use AQP)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
-- Run the same query but we can tolerate a 10% error ('with error 0.1')
-- 'behavior 'do_nothing' instructs snappydata to take no action even when error constraint is not met. See docs for details. 

select count(*) numOfRides,relative_error(numOFRides), CASE 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 1 THEN concat('Jan', 'a')
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 2 THEN 'Feb' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 3 THEN 'Mar' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 4 THEN 'Apr' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 5 THEN 'May' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 6 THEN 'Jun'
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 7 THEN 'Jul' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 8 THEN 'Aug' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 9 THEN 'Sep' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 10 THEN 'Oct' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 11 THEN 'Nov' 
WHEN month(pickup_datetime) = 12 THEN 'Dec'
END AS mnt from nyc_taxi_trip group by month(pickup_datetime) 
order by month(pickup_datetime) with error 0.1 behavior 'do_nothing' ;

paragraphs.title: How long does it take to ride from Midtown to Downtown?

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: How long does it take to ride from Midtown to Downtown?  (Use AQP)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql 

-- Absolute_error function provides a +/- error estimate 
-- 'with error' with no constraint indicates we can tolerate any error rate.
select avg(trip_time_in_secs/60) tripTime, hour(pickup_datetime) as hour, absolute_error(tripTime) from nyc_taxi_trip where pickup_latitude < 40.767588 and pickup_latitude > 40.749775 and pickup_longitude > -74.001632 and  pickup_longitude < -73.974595 and dropoff_latitude > 40.716800     and  dropoff_latitude <  40.717776 and dropoff_longitude >  -74.017682 and dropoff_longitude < -74.000945 group by hour(pickup_datetime) order by hour(pickup_datetime) with error;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Queries on Fare table

paragraphs.title: What are the most common tip percentages in NYC for rides?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql


-- Try switching payment types from CRD to CSH for credit card vs Cash tips
-- Most pay no tip when using cash. Hmm!
SELECT (ROUND( (tip_amount / fare_amount) * 100 )) tip_pct, avg(fare_amount), count(*) trips
FROM taxi_trip_fare WHERE payment_type = ${Select paymentType ='CRD','CRD'|'CSH'} and fare_amount > 0.00 and tip_amount < 50
GROUP BY (ROUND( tip_amount / fare_amount * 100 ))
ORDER BY (ROUND( tip_amount / fare_amount * 100 )) limit 30;

paragraphs.title: What are the most common tip percentages in NYC for rides?  (Use AQP)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

-- Payment type : 'CSH'(cash), 'CRD'(credit card), 'DIS'...
SELECT (ROUND( (tip_amount / fare_amount) * 100 )) tip_pct, avg(fare_amount), count(*) trips
FROM taxi_trip_fare WHERE 
payment_type = ${Select paymentType ='CRD','CRD'|'CSH'}
 and fare_amount > 0.00 and tip_amount < 50
GROUP BY (ROUND( tip_amount / fare_amount * 100 ))
ORDER BY (ROUND( tip_amount / fare_amount * 100 )) limit 30 with error ;

%angular

Try your own queries below ....
